page.title: 05AMMERDOWN AND BABINGTON
page.content: AMMERDOWN HOUSE designed by James Wyatt an example of the fashionable Palladian style. Standing in formal gardens and a large walled park a mile East of Kilmersdon, it was built in l789 by Thomas Samuel Jolliffe, an ancestor of the present Lord Hylton. The Column erected in l853 by Col. John Jolliffe is a prominent landmark on the skyline. BABINGTON HOUSE stands in parkland with a chain of lakes, a mile S.W. of Kilmersdon. Built in l703 by Mompesson, and a perfect example of Queen Anne architecture, it remained in possession of the Knatchbull family for 200 years. The present owners have restored the house. A tiny Wren church stands opposite the entrance. Although officially Babington Parish Church, the only community it now serves is the nearby hamlet of Newbury.
